description: Shortened from blitzkrieg, from German Blitzkrieg.

entries.meaning: (countable) A sudden attack, especially an air raid; usually with reference to the Blitz.
(countable) A swift and overwhelming attack or effort.
examples: We embarked on a publicity blitz, putting posters and flyers all around town.

entries.meaning: (countable, American football) A play in which additional defenders beyond the defensive linemen rush the passer.
(cooking) The act of blending or puréeing food using a blender or processor.

verbs.description: blitz (third-person singular simple present blitzes, present participle blitzing, simple past and past participle blitzed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To attack quickly or suddenly, as by an air raid or similar action.
(intransitive, American football) To perform a blitz.
examples: The Washington High defense almost always blitzes on third down.

entries.meaning: (transitive, cooking) To purée or chop (food products) using a food processor or blender.
examples: To make nut roast, you have to blitz the nuts in the food processor before adding the parsley and breadcrumbs.

entries.meaning: (transitive, informal) To do something quickly or in one session.
examples: Synonyms: hurry, zoom; see also Thesaurus:rush
